comments.commentBody: mytwocents, I agree with you that, it's the powerful black money-crime-politics nexus that's playing havoc with common lives, rendering the representative democracy a mere sham. Thanks.

How is the ungrammatical "him ... is" a correction?  Was it a typo for "his going"?  I'm reminded of Obama's saying during his first term, "Me reaching out to [Republicans] was genuine."  Mr. President, "me" can neither be an adjective modify "reaching" nor serve as subject of the sentence.
I am 85 and I quit my job at 57 because I could not remember names under pressure. There is hope - and a good spell checker.

Snark alert, Gary you just doubleposted about cognitive decline, you might want to get yourself checked out.

Greenspan is total fraud. Recall among other things, he counselled against using the Clinton surplus to pay down the debt. US creditors would lose confidence in US as a borrower. More blather.

Speaking of age related cognitive decline, I'm just 51 but I often suspect that I'm already affected myself, and that might explain why I find myself noticing errors in my comments only after I've posted them. It's hard for me to be too sympathetic to an 87 year old who had so much influence on policy for so long who apparently still hasn't accepted that he ain't considered the Maestro anymore, or at least he isn't by anyone who isn't a complete sucker for right wing propaganda. Here's the earlier comment resubmitted, but now I've got to start my class.

Greenspan is 87 years old, and while it's not unusual for someone to be wise at that age, it's not at all unusual for some major age related cognitive decline to have set in by around eighty either. I'm not sure about his lifetime achievements, but him going around preaching about macroeconomic policy, monetary or fiscal - even though his pronouncements over the last 13 years have been among the most widely discredited out there (thanks to Paul Krugman and a few others) - is surely about as pathetic as it gets for economists in that league. Throw him a bone of some kind Professor Krugman, he deserves it, literally.

What a surprise! A judgment against a bank that will "hardly dent their bottom line" and no one is held criminally liable. I suspect that if a banker were found to have murdered someone in pursuit of profit, there would be only a fine and, of course, not even a demand for an apology. Our system isn't only broken. It seems to be beyond repair.

Whoa! What do you do there at the U, Benson? Janitor?

Ignoring the fact that this guy has no engineering credentials and his scheme may well be infeasible, are you sure you want to suddenly remove *all* the CO2 produced since 1750 (remember some part of this is already in the oceans)? What happens if the temperature dives and ice sheets begin forming in the NH? Are you going to try adding back "just the right amount"? What if nothing happens, or the temperature just keeps going up?

This kind of "go for broke" scheme scares me more than doing nothing. If you end up nudging the climate into the next glacial phase--possibly rather quickly--how many will die?

Off topic but

Emergency 20-year Drawdown of Excess CO2 via Push-Pull Ocean Pumps
http://climatecolab.org/web/guest/plans/-/plans/contestId/20/planId/1303629

appears to be the best plan I have seen. A far better use of some hundreds of billions that wasting those sums in the so-called Department of Defense.

KJ,
"It's hard to highlight a post that effectively attacks a parenting decision, and many of the posts encouraging medication are vigorous enough to suggest that criticism."

I had NO idea that the "NYT picks" have to be in support of the blogger's position. Is this an official NYT position or is this a personal preference as a moderator?

As far as the "pro med" posts are suggestive of criticism -- so what? I thought this is a discussion and people have different points of views. If the blogger were so comfortable about her decision (and its consequences), why post here for comments?

There's a line between agreeing with the author, and attacking the choice. When it comes to medicating a child, the topic is so sensitive and the opinions so strong that it's likely I didn't see a good comment to highlight. I often choose a strong opinion on the opposite side of something to highlight, or make the comment of the moment, to spark further conversation.

But here, the parent didn't ask for advice about medicating the child, and debate on that issue is not the goal of the quandary. So I really didn't hone in on that question, and again, I don't have a strong opinion on the question of medication for children with ADHD (and certainly not about this child). I take the quandary as presented and go from there, and it's reasonably clear that advice on medication isn't something the parent here is interested in.

This is an excellent point. It is important to note that the type of HPV varies in different populations. For example a study of women from Belgium with high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL),showed that he percentage of women with HSIL in the entire study population attributable to infection with a particular type (AR(pop) %) was highest for HPV16 (32%), followed by HPV31 (22%), HPV39 (11%), and HPV52 (11%). HPV18 was responsible for 7% of the HSIL lesions.
Elimination of HPV16 and HPV18 is expected to reduce the prevalence HSIL with 37%. That means that in Belgium the HPV used in the vaccines does NOT cover the total dominant HPV causing cancers in Belgium. This is just one example

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19124515

Even more important it shows that the types of HPV that can cause cancer can replace the ones that are covered.

There is a very real possibility as we decrease some types of HPV, different and potentially more deadly types will start to dominate.

I took that biaxin at 6 years old and swear to god I will never forget it. Gave me respect for medicine & the importance of sacrifice for healing sometimes.

ditch the bubblegum folks.

Excellent article. It's much easier to give kids what they want in the short run but everybody suffers the consequences in the long run.
Helen
Boomers, Markets & Money

Wow, I didn't realize that spending an extra buck fifty at the pharmacy to get the medicine that tastes slightly unpleasant is "letting the kids run the show". I thought it was just being compassionate and considerate. Does this mean I should stop getting special flavors when I pick up medicines for my mom and grandma too?

Mmm, some college students who graduated high school on time are actually still 17, and there are some every year who graduated a term or a year early - and that's not even counting kids who take college courses while still enrolled in high school.

My stepmother is a prosecutor, and one night at dinner my 16 year old brother made an offhand remark about how he didn't have to worry about getting in trouble with the law because she'd get him off if he did anything.  Without missing a beat she reminded him that she was a prosecutor and told him that if he did anything illegal she would be the first in line to make sure he paid.  No matter how much he pressed, she wouldn't back down, and it worked - to this day, three years later, he hasn't had any trouble with the law.
We have something to do with it (them).
I know someone whose daughter in law school did the same thing and the father intervened.  She's now a lawyer working for the attorney general's office.

I disagree that this generation of kids is somehow different than earlier generations.  They are just more coddled, and parents these days project a neediness onto them.  My 11 year old son is in the middle of his two week Boy Scout camp in the High Sierras with a group of counselors and his troop mates and is having the time of his life.  Neither his dad or I are there, and the resiliency and independence he learns there carries on throughout his life.  How do I know - he did it last year at the age of 10.

A "nick name" is something earned, as in "Fleet Feet" for the kid who runs so far and fast. A "diminutive, however, is a shortening, a lessening, of someone's name. Using a diminutive to call upon someone, as when people call Johns Johnny and Jessicas Jessi, is a heavy handed and sure fire way to reduce the potential of any child. Name a child; then respect that person by calling him or her by their given name.

How odd, to cite happiness as the justification for moral behavior. Do the right thing, because later on you'll feel better about yourself. Huh? How about saying, do the right thing simply because it's right? Or even, don't do the wrong thing because it will harm others (which, in the case of plagiarism, is quite true). There is something disturbing about this self-serving logic.

DJS, I know some people think misery builds character, but is that really the hill you want to die on? I'm sure that Lisa doesn't indulge her kids' every whim, but really - it isn't a crime spend a few dollars more so a sick child can have a medicine that won't make them gag.

You don't deliberately buy medicine for yourself in a flavor YOU can't stand, I wager, so why hold the kids to an arbitrarily higher standard?

Not to mention, if you're giving medicine to, say, a child with migraines or asthma (or both - hilariously, they tend to run together), and the dyes trigger migraines, asthma, or both, you're going to be really annoyed on day three when you realize how stupid you've been.

(Do you know how hard it is to get children's painkillers, no extra medicine for sinus congestion or fever or what have you, without dyes?)

You know, it never occurred to me until today that it was wrong to EVER take the preferences of my child into account, even if they were sick. From now on, I will no longer encourage the kids to have their own opinions, and I will always carefully do the exact opposite of what they want, just to make them suffer. Can't let them "win", after all, gotta maintain power at all costs.

Yessiree, the days of listening to my kids are gone! Buying the flavor of medicine they like when they are sick is exactly the same as giving in to their every whim at all times. Definitely. From now on, the only orders I will slavishly follow are those of the biddy brigade. Tell me, folks, do you have an opinion on hairstyle? Which says "stern disciplinarian" better - braids or a bun?
The writer mother in E Nesbit's "The Railway Children" is one of the best!

Is there any proof that women with children are less productive than other workers? Or is it just that a) they're logging fewer hours or b) they're less productive than they were before they had kids? (which doesn't necessarily mean less productive than other workers).

At any given point, my workplace is full of people not working - they're on social networks or reading news sites or chatting in the kitchen. But as long as the work is getting done, I don't see the issue. Deciding that one group is less productive than others - without substantiating in any real, measurable way - is discrimination, pure and simple.

As for parental leave itself - or any kind of leave - a few months is nothing. There's a lot I'd do to hang on to a good employee - I'd like to meet an employer who can honestly say they'd rather lose a good employee than give them some subsidized time off. (I shudder to think of what it must be like for poor or uneducated women. Disgraceful.)

I think it is always nicer to introduce our partners, be they spouse or not, as a part of our life. It's a sweet way of acknowledging to them that they are special more than as any kind of explanation for other people.

I like "mi amor'" or maybe "this is my sweetheart John". I'd ask The Viking his preference.

Thanks for the lovely story of both your dear Elliot and of your new love. Best wishes to you and yours.
Marketing idea: diapers with appropriate genitalia drawn on them so no one accidentally gets it wrong!  No worries about baby ingesting the fake hair!
What else is there aside from play time for a 9 month old? (in addition to sleeping and eating).
